segment.source: Add sound
segment.target: Add sound

segment.source: In this step, we examine how the shooting game sample creates an object for sound playback using the XAudio2 APIs.
segment.target: In this step, we examine how the shooting game sample creates an object for sound playback using the XAudio2 APIs.

segment.source: Add sound
segment.target: Add sound

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: In this step, we examine how the shooting game sample creates an object for sound playback using the XAudio2 APIs.
segment.target: In this step, we examine how the shooting game sample creates an object for sound playback using the XAudio2 APIs.

segment.source: Objective
segment.target: Objective

segment.source: To add sound output using XAudio2.
segment.target: To add sound output using XAudio2.

segment.source: In the game sample, the audio objects and behaviors are defined in three files:
segment.target: In the game sample, the audio objects and behaviors are defined in three files:

segment.source: Audio.h/.cpp.
segment.target: Audio.h/.cpp.

segment.source: This code file defines the Audio object, which contains the XAudio2 resources for sound playback.
segment.target: This code file defines the Audio object, which contains the XAudio2 resources for sound playback.

segment.source: It also defines the method for suspending and resuming audio playback if the game is paused or deactivated.
segment.target: It also defines the method for suspending and resuming audio playback if the game is paused or deactivated.

segment.source: MediaReader.h/.cpp.
segment.target: MediaReader.h/.cpp.

segment.source: This code defines the methods for reading audio .wav files from local storage.
segment.target: This code defines the methods for reading audio .wav files from local storage.

segment.source: SoundEffect.h/.cpp.
segment.target: SoundEffect.h/.cpp.

segment.source: This code defines an object for in-game sound playback.
segment.target: This code defines an object for in-game sound playback.

segment.source: Defining the audio engine
segment.target: Defining the audio engine

segment.source: When the game sample starts, it creates an Audio object that allocates the audio resources for the game.
segment.target: When the game sample starts, it creates an Audio object that allocates the audio resources for the game.

segment.source: The code that declares this object looks like this:
segment.target: The code that declares this object looks like this:

segment.source: The Audio::MusicEngine and Audio::SoundEffectEngine methods return references to IXAudio2 objects that define the mastering voice for each audio type.
segment.target: The Audio::MusicEngine and Audio::SoundEffectEngine methods return references to IXAudio2 objects that define the mastering voice for each audio type.

segment.source: A mastering voice is the audio device used for playback.
segment.target: A mastering voice is the audio device used for playback.

segment.source: Sound data buffers cannot be submitted directly to mastering voices, but data submitted to other types of voices must be directed to a mastering voice to be heard.
segment.target: Sound data buffers cannot be submitted directly to mastering voices, but data submitted to other types of voices must be directed to a mastering voice to be heard.

segment.source: Initializing the audio resources
segment.target: Initializing the audio resources

segment.source: The sample initializes the IXAudio2 objects for the music and sound effect engines with calls to XAudio2Create.
segment.target: The sample initializes the IXAudio2 objects for the music and sound effect engines with calls to XAudio2Create.

segment.source: After the engines have been instantiated, it creates a mastering voice for each with calls to IXAudio2::CreateMasteringVoice, as here:
segment.target: After the engines have been instantiated, it creates a mastering voice for each with calls to IXAudio2::CreateMasteringVoice, as here:

segment.source: As a music or sound effect audio file is loaded, this method calls IXAudio2::CreateSourceVoice on the mastering voice, which creates an instance of a source voice for playback.
segment.target: As a music or sound effect audio file is loaded, this method calls IXAudio2::CreateSourceVoice on the mastering voice, which creates an instance of a source voice for playback.

segment.source: We look at the code for this as soon as we finish reviewing how the game sample loads audio files.
segment.target: We look at the code for this as soon as we finish reviewing how the game sample loads audio files.

segment.source: Reading an audio file
segment.target: Reading an audio file

segment.source: In the game sample, the code for reading audio format files is defined in MediaReader.cpp.
segment.target: In the game sample, the code for reading audio format files is defined in MediaReader.cpp.

segment.source: The specific method that reads in an encoded .wav audio file, MediaReader::LoadMedia, looks like this:
segment.target: The specific method that reads in an encoded .wav audio file, MediaReader::LoadMedia, looks like this:

segment.source: This method uses the Media Foundation APIs to read in the .wav audio file as a Pulse Code Modulation (PCM) buffer.
segment.target: This method uses the Media Foundation APIs to read in the .wav audio file as a Pulse Code Modulation (PCM) buffer.

segment.source: Creates a media source reader (IMFSourceReader) object by calling MFCreateSourceReaderFromURL.
segment.target: Creates a media source reader (IMFSourceReader) object by calling MFCreateSourceReaderFromURL.

segment.source: Creates a media type (IMFMediaType) for the decoding of the audio file by calling MFCreateMediaType.
segment.target: Creates a media type (IMFMediaType) for the decoding of the audio file by calling MFCreateMediaType.

segment.source: This method specifies that the decoded output is PCM audio, which is an audio type that XAudio2 can use.
segment.target: This method specifies that the decoded output is PCM audio, which is an audio type that XAudio2 can use.

segment.source: Sets the decoded output media type for the reader by calling IMFSourceReader::SetCurrentMediaType.
segment.target: Sets the decoded output media type for the reader by calling IMFSourceReader::SetCurrentMediaType.

segment.source: Creates a WAVEFORMATEX buffer and copies the results of a call to IMFMediaType::MFCreateWaveFormatExFromMFMediaType on the IMFMediaType object.
segment.target: Creates a WAVEFORMATEX buffer and copies the results of a call to IMFMediaType::MFCreateWaveFormatExFromMFMediaType on the IMFMediaType object.

segment.source: This formats the buffer that holds the audio file after it is loaded.
segment.target: This formats the buffer that holds the audio file after it is loaded.

segment.source: Gets the duration, in seconds, of the audio stream by calling IMFSourceReader::GetPresentationAttribute and then converts the duration to bytes.
segment.target: Gets the duration, in seconds, of the audio stream by calling IMFSourceReader::GetPresentationAttribute and then converts the duration to bytes.

segment.source: Reads the audio file in as a stream by calling IMFSourceReader::ReadSample.
segment.target: Reads the audio file in as a stream by calling IMFSourceReader::ReadSample.

segment.source: Copies the contents of the audio sample buffer into an array returned by the method.
segment.target: Copies the contents of the audio sample buffer into an array returned by the method.

segment.source: The most important thing in SoundEffect::Initialize is the creation of the source voice object, m\_sourceVoice, from the mastering voice.
segment.target: The most important thing in SoundEffect::Initialize is the creation of the source voice object, m\_sourceVoice, from the mastering voice.

segment.source: We use the source voice for the actual play back of the sound data buffer obtained from MediaReader::LoadMedia.
segment.target: We use the source voice for the actual play back of the sound data buffer obtained from MediaReader::LoadMedia.

segment.source: The sample game calls this method when it initializes the SoundEffect object, like this:
segment.target: The sample game calls this method when it initializes the SoundEffect object, like this:

segment.source: This method is passed the results of calls to Audio::SoundEffectEngine (or Audio::MusicEngine), MediaReader::GetOutputWaveFormatEx, and the buffer returned by a call to MediaReader::LoadMedia, as seen here.
segment.target: This method is passed the results of calls to Audio::SoundEffectEngine (or Audio::MusicEngine), MediaReader::GetOutputWaveFormatEx, and the buffer returned by a call to MediaReader::LoadMedia, as seen here.

segment.source: SoundEffect::Initialize is called from the Simple3DGame:Initialize method that initializes the main game object.
segment.target: SoundEffect::Initialize is called from the Simple3DGame:Initialize method that initializes the main game object.

segment.source: Now that the sample game has an audio file in memory, let's see how it plays it back during game play!
segment.target: Now that the sample game has an audio file in memory, let's see how it plays it back during game play!

segment.source: Playing back an audio file
segment.target: Playing back an audio file

segment.source: To play the sound, this method uses the source voice object m\_sourceVoice to start the playback of the sound data buffer m\_soundData.
segment.target: To play the sound, this method uses the source voice object m\_sourceVoice to start the playback of the sound data buffer m\_soundData.

segment.source: It creates an XAUDIO2\_BUFFER, to which it provides a reference to the sound data buffer, and then submits it with a call to IXAudio2SourceVoice::SubmitSourceBuffer.
segment.target: It creates an XAUDIO2\_BUFFER, to which it provides a reference to the sound data buffer, and then submits it with a call to IXAudio2SourceVoice::SubmitSourceBuffer.

segment.source: With the sound data queued up, SoundEffect::PlaySound starts play back by calling IXAudio2SourceVoice::Start.
segment.target: With the sound data queued up, SoundEffect::PlaySound starts play back by calling IXAudio2SourceVoice::Start.

segment.source: Now, whenever a collision between the ammo and a target occurs, a call to SoundEffect::PlaySound causes a noise to play.
segment.target: Now, whenever a collision between the ammo and a target occurs, a call to SoundEffect::PlaySound causes a noise to play.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: That was a whirlwind tour of Universal Windows Platform (UWP) DirectX game development!
segment.target: That was a whirlwind tour of Universal Windows Platform (UWP) DirectX game development!

segment.source: At this point, you have an idea of what you need to do to make your own game for Windows 8 a great experience.
segment.target: At this point, you have an idea of what you need to do to make your own game for Windows 8 a great experience.

segment.source: Remember, your game can be played on a wide variety of Windows 8 devices and platforms, so design your components: your graphics, your controls, your user interface, and your audio for as wide a set of configurations as you can!
segment.target: Remember, your game can be played on a wide variety of Windows 8 devices and platforms, so design your components: your graphics, your controls, your user interface, and your audio for as wide a set of configurations as you can!

segment.source: For more info about ways to modify the game sample provided in these documents, see Extending the game sample.
segment.target: For more info about ways to modify the game sample provided in these documents, see Extending the game sample.
